Led by Action Against Hunger and including seven national and international partners, the "Consortium project to improve the well-being and health amongst the refugee and host communities in Cox's Bazar" was aimed at improving the well-being and health amongst refugee and local population in Cox’s Bazar (Bangladesh). The project aims to foster equitable and non-discriminatory access to multiple services, including community-based healthcare, nutrition, education, water supply and sanitation, and transitional shelters. The project designed through a participatory approach and implemented in close connection with target communities, especially through the partnership with community-based multi-functional centres. Specific target of the project included women, children, pregnant/lactating women, persons with disabilities, the elderly, as well as gender-based violence and conflict-affected survivors.

A harmonized consortium approach to providing multipurpose cash assistance to effectively meet the basic needs of vulnerable conflict-affected households, reduce negative coping mechanisms, enhance access to civil documentation, and promote transition to recovery

DFID is seeking a service provider to act as Managing Agent (MA) for  the implementation of the Education Quality Improvement Programme in Tanzania (EQUIP-T) over the next four years and provide associated administrative services for the benefit of the Government of Tanzania. Cambridge Education will be lead, IRC will be subbing.

A surge of violence in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) drove large numbers of Congolese and displaced Burundians in DRC into Burundi. IRC is providing emergency protection services and material support for the most vulnerable in transit centers in Burundi. In particular, these services focus on separated and unaccompanied minors, survivors of GBV, and people with specific needs in the transit centers.

DFID has awarded the BRCIS Consortium led by NRC of which IRC is a member funds to respond to the ongoing emergency in Somalia providing multipurpose cash as well a a health/wash interventions . IRC Somalia has been requested to respond as part of the BRCIS consortium

DFID is seeking a service provider (SP) to provide verification of partner deliverables, an enhanced capacity to provide and regularly champion accountability to affected people and develop, manage and promote a protracted crisis learning hub. This will be required for the lifetime of the Building Resilience and an effective Emergency Refugee response (BRAER) programme. The grant will run for a three-year period, with a potential extension, and will deliver against three core outputs. U-LEARN will inform adaptive programming from the outset and will include annual periods of joint SP, DFID and partners’ review and reflection. It will have built in flexibility to deliver additional outputs as negotiated through periodic work plans to be agreed between the SP and DFID.

As a follow up to BRCIS1, The BRCiS Consortium will use adaptive management and community-designed and led solutions to build resilience to local shocks and stresses. It focuses on reinforcing social cohesion and natural resource management capacities, fostering economic opportunities, and enabling access to basic services through approaches that adapt to learning, changing contexts, and community-driven priorities. DFID has confirmed a total of GBP 16 million to the BRCiS consortium to support this project.

EQUAL   is   a   multi-country   research   consortium   generating   evidence   on   effective   approaches      to   deliver   life-saving   maternal   and   newborn   health   care   in   countries   affected   by   conflict.   We  are    a    group  of    research  partners  united  in  our  shared  commitment  to  reduce  maternal  and  neonatal  deaths  by  ensuring  quality  health  services  are  accessible  to  every  woman  and  newborn,  regardless  of  where  they  live.    Our  work  focuses  on  the  DRC,  Nigeria,  Somalia,  and  South  Sudan  –  countries  with  the  highest  burden  of  maternal  and  neonatal  deaths  worldwide.
ERICC aims to deliver, and maximise uptake of new, operationally and policy relevant evidence on: the most effective approaches to education delivery in conflict and protected crisis contexts.

Assumptions: All Consortium members are willing to install direct data import functionality, rather than forcing users to upload data manually. Learning questions: What is the level of satisfaction with SCAN among users, in terms of (1) the usability of the tool itself, and (2) the utility of the results to inform decisions. How does this user satisfaction change based on the amount of training and support people receive? Is there some minimum package of support we must provide? Risks: SCAN gets applied in projects which don’t have high enough quality data to make results meaningful. SCAN gets applied to projects with no comparative data points available, so results are hard to interpret and act upon.

Assumptions: Learning questions: What conditions are necessary, in terms of commitments to data security or transparency, to make implementing agencies comfortable signing on to a project of this kind? What kind of financial support will be necessary once this grant ends, to sustain the multi-agency SCAN tool? How well would the “business model” from for-profit humanitarian (e.g. CommCare), centrally funded (e.g. DHIS2), or subscription based software projects apply to SCAN? Risks: agencies’ hesitation about data transparency preventing them from joining the Consortium—both the security of underlying financial data stored central databases, and the concern that results data will be used out of context to judge programs unfairly

Assumptions: -sufficient in-country pilots with which to field-test SCAN -sector leads are willing to champion production and use of rigorous cost analysis in coordination groups Learning questions: What incentives prompt country programs to want to use SCAN (e.g. Donor reporting requirements? Donor requirements around adaptive programming? HQ-based push? Clear learning/planning needs?) What factors make implementing agencies more/less willing to share SCAN results in sector forums? What additional information about programs is necessary to be able to interpret cost-efficiency results, and learn from the data? Risks: sector learning groups (e.g. Cash GB workstream) are not responsive enough to begin sharing and reflecting on data within grant time frame
Focus Groups Discussions (FGDs), Key Informant Interviews (KIIs), Co-design workshop with target group
